blocks.text: Feb. 12, 1956 - Gordon, Cindy and Kathy visit the grave-yard of St. John's Episcopal Church, Pequea, one of the oldest graveyards in this locality, located just beyond the Lancaster County line in Chester County. The church was established about 1728. Inscriptions are unique.

The oldest stone, that of George Boyd, is dated 1731: The inscription on John Coombe's stone reads: "Behold ye place Where I doe Lie/ As thou art now so ones was I/ As I am now so shalt thou be/ Prepare for death and follow me". Peter Bezellon stone reads: "Who'er thou art with tender Heart/ Stop, Read, & think on Me/ I once were as well as now thou art/ As now I am so thou shalt be." Martha Bezellon stone reads: "All you that come my Grave to see/ And as I am so must you be/ Repent in turne, no time delay/ For sudden I was snatched away".

blocks.text: Late February - a heavy wind storm takes down a tree on State St., missing our car by the width of one house. (Kathy on tree)

Louise (third from left), with two other children in the neighborhood, spend many hours making sixty pot holders, which they sell for $15, donating the proceeds to the Blind Association. For their efforts, they receive a three column picture in the morning newspaper. (Newspaper photograph)

blocks.text: A trip to Asheville, N. C. to attend the State Convention of the North Carolina Education Association. March 21 - 25, 1956. Gordon and Walter McClair represent Educators Mutual Insurance Company. Total trip - 1,220 miles.

Scenes in and near Harpers Ferry, W. Va., a town which is securing a new lease on life since Congress has voted to restore it as a National Monument. Here John Brown led his revolt of the slaves just prior to the Civil War.

blocks.text: Outside St. Augustine, we again take the coastal road, with frequent ocean vistas.
Entrance to Marineland, where two giant tanks holding 700,000,000 gallons of water contain many varieties of sea creatures, which can be viewed through portholes.
Caught at the exact moment a huge porpoise leaps into the air to secure a fish from the hand of an attendant. Action stopped at 1/1250 sec.

blocks.text: Across central Florida to Anna Maria Island, near Bradenton, where we take a dip in the Gulf of Mexico. Our motel is only a block from the water. The next day we meet with the chairman of the insurance committee in Bradenton.
Florida has become one of the Nation's largest cattle raising states. The forests have been cleared with bulldozers for grazing land.

blocks.text: The Miami Serpentarium, south of the city on R#1, is owned and operated by Bill Haast. Here is to be found one of the finest collections of poisonous snakes. There are 350 cobras, representing eight species, as well many other poisonous and non-poisonous varieties from many different countries. Some of the snakes must be kept under controlled temperatures. Haast has been bitten twenty three times by cobras, but never by the king cobra. It is doubtful if any one has ever survived the bite of a king cobra whose bite contains enough venom to kill twenty men.
One of the most dangerous jobs in the world. Here Bill Haast prepares to seize a king cobra with his left hand while distracting the snake's attention with his right.

blocks.text: After being secured, the king cobra's venom is extracted by forcing the fangs through a rubber sheet. About half a c.c. of venom is ejected. The dried venom, used as a pain killer, is worth $12,000 per ounce. After the venom is extracted, it is then necessary to force feed the snake with a special formula, after which the snake is returned to its pen.
Besides snakes, the Serpentarium also has a bad tempered little alligator and a Nile crocodile which can catch a running man.

blocks.text: The Everglades National Park, the largest tropical wilderness in the country, embraces 1,500,000 acres of swampy wilds at the southern end of the Florida peninsula. Most of it remains impenetrable to sightseers. Although some roads and trails have been opened by the National Park Service, most of the Park remains in an undeveloped state. The Park was established in 1947.
ELEVATION THREE FEET

blocks.text: November 24, 1956 - Nancy on her seventeenth birthday is attired in a new dress; is about to attend a surprise birthday party for her at the Hotel Brunswick.

November, 1956 - Gordon, accompanied by Kitty, makes a business trip to Findlay, Ohio. On the way they visit Dick and Charlotte Andes in Columbus and see a Big Ten football game in which Michigan defeats Ohio State 19 - 0.
Dressed for the big game: Kitty, Gordon, Chotz and Dick. Yes, it's cold!
Mike and Liz Andes.
George and Dotty England bid us good-bye as we leave Findlay for home. Sky overcast with threat of snow.

Mike and Liz Andes.

George and Dotty England bid us good-bye as we leave Findlay for home. Sky overcast with threat of snow.

blocks.text: June 14-16, 1957 - Gordon spends a hot week end with Jack Herr near the Wye River in Maryland. The cabin is a converted schoolhouse.
Nearby is the Wye Oak, said to be the largest white oak in the United States.

Arlene and Bill Robinson,
Bill Robinson,
Claude and Betty Smith, Kitty.
The children use our new aluminum cot as their table.
Entertaining in the back yard.

blocks.text: June 29–30, 1957 – Gordon and Kitty, accompanied by Cindy and Kathy, drive to Gloucester, Virginia (near Yorktown) to attend the wedding of Jack Stanley and Elizabeth Corr. Return via Yorktown, Williamsburg and Richmond. Total - 612 miles.
The old Ware Church where the wedding takes place was built about 1693, with bricks brought from England.
A gay collection of flowered hats on the female guests at the reception at the home of the bride's parents.

blocks.text: The York River and the beautiful Colonial Parkway between Yorktown and Williamsburg.

Williamsburg, the extensively restored former capital of Virginia (until 1778), owes its restoration to the generosity of John D. Rockefeller, Jr. The population of the town probably never exceeded 2,000, but it was as the social and cultural center of Colonial Virginia. More than 300 buildings have been restored.
The Capitol.
The Governor's Palace.
The Powder Magazine.

blocks.text: Cindy andnddKathy agree they have been in more comfortable spots.
Right - entrance to William and Mary College, chartered 1693.
We follow Route #5 through deep forests to Richmond. Driveways off this route lead to plantations along the James Riv.

In Capitol Square, Richmond,
is equestrian statue of Geo.
Washington, with sculptured
figures of noted Virginians.

The Capitol of Virginia, designed by Jeff-
erson, is oldest representative legislative legislature in America.
End - trip to Virginia.

blocks.text: Early July '57.

On one of the hottest days of the hottest days of the summer, a drive to Hackettstown, N. J., with Uncle Jim to visit his son, Rory, at camp.

blocks.text: August 3 - 18, 1957 - The Landreths take a motor trip to Eastern Canada, visiting New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, and Quebec, including Cape Breton Island and the Gaspe Peninsula. Total trip - 4,300 miles.
Refer to special book devoted to the trip.
High above the Atlantic at "The Ovens" in Nova Scotia.
The Cabot Trail, Cape Breton Island, one of the outstanding sea and land roads in the Western Hemisphere.
Perce Rock and village on Gaspe Peninsula.

She is buried in Ream's Cemetery, near Reamstown, Pa., alongside Gordon's father who died March 20, 1930. Her memory is treasured by her family who loved her.

October 2, 1957 - Grandmother Landreth dies quietly in her sleep after a series of heart attacks over a period of several years. She is buried in Ream's Cemetery, near Reamstown, Pa., alongside Gordon's father who died March 20, 1930. Her memory is treasured by her family who loved her.

November 14 – 18, 1957 - Gordon and Kitty visit Dick and Chotz Andes in Columbus, Ohio, and see a football game in which Ohio State defeats Iowa 17 - 13 which sends Ohio State to the Rose Bowl.
